wikipedia_page.main: Thomas "Tom" Francis Kiely (25 August 1869 – 6 November 1951) was an Irish athlete.

response: * Tom Kiely, Olympic decathlon gold medalist at the 1904 Summer Olympics, from Ballyneale, just outside the town.
* Tom Kiely establishes a world record in the hammer event. He becomes the first man to throw the hammer more than 160 feet.

link_mentions.page: Great Britain at the 1904 Summer Olympics
response: With this classification, Tom Kiely, who won gold in the all-around athletics event, refused offers of a free trip and reimbursement of travel expenses from British and American officials, paid his own way, and was insistent that he represented Ireland.IOC database: Great Britain medallists at 1904 Olympics

Tom Kiely, who won the "all-around" athletics competition at the 1904 Olympics in St Louis is also listed as competing for Great Britain.Thomas Francis Kiely, Great Britain Olympic.org He had raised funds in counties Tipperary and Waterford to travel independently and compete for Ireland. Frank Zarnowski does not regard the 1904 event as part of the Olympic competition, and also doubts the story that Kiely had refused offers by both the English Amateur Athletic Association (AAA) and the New York Athletic Club to pay his fare and cover his travel expenses so he could compete for them. Peter Lovesey disagrees with Zarnowski.

Born in County Limerick, Ireland, Ryan won his first Irish hammer title in 1902, beating the great Tom Kiely. In 1910 Ryan emigrated to America. After placing third in the 1911 AAU championship in his first year he improved to take second place in 1912, and won the title in 1913. With the exception of 1918 when he was in Europe with the American Armed Forces he won the AAU title every year from then up to and including 1921, when he retired.

link_mentions.page: Athletics at the 1904 Summer Olympics – Men's all-around
response: 7 athletes from 2 nations competed. Tom Kiely, an Irishman, won with 6036 points.
